column1: Dear Mr. Morse:It was very pleasant to me to get a letter from you the other day. Perhaps I should have found it pleasanter if I had been able to decipher it. I don't think that I mastered anything beyond the date (which I knew) and the signature (at which I guessed).There's a singular and perpetual charm in a letter of yours—it never grows old; it never loses its novelty. One can say to one's self every morning: "There's that letter of Morse's. I haven't read it yet. I think I'll take another shy at it today
column2: and maybe I shall be able in the course of a few days to make out what he means by those t's that look like w's
column3: and those i's that haven't any eyebrows."Other letters are read
column5: and forgotten; but yours are kept forever—unread. One of them will last a reasonable man a lifetime.Admiringly yours
